TextEng: <nickname>, what’s this?
This black smudge on\nthe piece of bread.
Gah, mold!|Huh. Mold.

TextKor: 먹다 만 빵이 있었다는 걸\n까먹었어…. 버려야겠다.
TextEng: I forgot I had some left-over\nbread. I should throw it away.
What’s “mold”? I feel like you don’t like it.

TextKor: 곰팡이는 습하거나 어두운 곳, 상하거나\n썩은 음식 등에서 피어나는 생물이야.
TextEng: It’s what grows in damp or dark\nplaces, or on spoiled or rotten food.
Sorry about that.

TextKor: 지구에 온 첫날부터\n이런 걸 보게 하다니.
TextEng: I hope you don’t get the wrong idea\nabout Earth on your first day here.

TextKor: 얼른 치워야겠다. 그럼\n책상이 훨씬 깨끗해질 거야!
TextEng: I’ll get rid of it. That’ll make\nthe desk much cleaner!
Damp or dark places…
Spoiled or rotten food?
Oh. Oh….
<nickname>, wait.
Wait. Don’t throw it away.

TextKor: 나, 얘와 시간을 보내 보고 싶어.
TextEng: I’d like to spend time with it.
May I?
But why? Isn’t it dirty and gross?
Please, <nickname>.
‘If it’s just for a few days…’
Alright then.
Hello?
I saw terrible filth on the moon.

TextKor: 지구에도 그런 게 있니.\n너도 그곳에서 태어났어?
TextEng: Is there filth on Earth as well?\nWere you born from it too?

TextKor: … 넌 썩은 꿈의 시체에서도.\n피어날 수 있어?
TextEng: Can you grow on the\ncorpses of rotten dreams?

TextKor: 넌 불결하고 냄새 나는\n것들을 두려워하지 않아?
TextEng: Are you not afraid of dirty,\nfoul-smelling things?
Are you not afraid of me?
Why?
… What for?
How very strange.
But thank you.
Really.
We’re alike, you and me.

TextKor: 인간들이 친구라고 부르는\n걸 우리도 할 수 있겠어.
TextEng: Perhaps we can be what\nhumans call friends.
<nickname>!
I was so absorbed I didn’t\neven hear your footsteps.

TextKor: 몽상하던 나를 눈 뜨게\n하는 것인데도 말이야.
TextEng: Even though it usually wakes\nme from my daydreams.
I’m sorry.

TextKor: 나를 찾았어? 혹시\n나를 몇 번이나 불렀어?
TextEng: Were you looking for me?\nDid you call out my name?

TextKor: 아냐, 나도 방금 왔으니 괜찮아.|무슨 일이 있는 걸까 걱정했어.
TextEng: That’s alright, I just got here.|I was worried something had happened.
You’re sweet. Like a soft, fluffy cloud.
What were you so absorbed in, Dot?
A book!
I’m enchanted by an act called ‘reading’.

TextKor: 책은 아주 오래되고 투명한 마법 같아,\n날 붙잡고 그 안으로 속절없이 끌어당기지.
TextEng: Books are magical, they capture\nmy soul and draw me in.

TextKor: 그 체계는 다른 매체와는 조금 달라.
TextEng: Their inner workings are\nsomething special.

TextKor: 정말이야, 내가 정말이지 필요로\n하는 표현 방식을 구사해, 어떤 책은!
TextEng: Really, some books truly do\nspeak the very language I crave!
From poems that are loudest\nwhen words are left unsaid,

TextKor: 켜켜히 쌓이며 이야기를 만들어 내는\n소설은 내가 특히 좋아하는 종류야.
TextEng: to novels that care for each and every\nintricate layer of the narrative.
They ask me,

TextKor: “내가 하는 말을 있는\n그대로 느낄 수 있어?”
TextEng: in a sweet undertone,
“Do you feel me word by word?”

TextKor: 가끔은 책과 내가 주고받는\n놀이처럼 느껴질 수도 있지!
TextEng: Sometimes like a friendly exchange\nthat takes place in complete silence!

TextKor: 그 모든 것들이 날 빠지게 만든 거야.
TextEng: And that’s what enchants me.
(An alien creature in love with a book. What are the odds.)

TextKor: (낭만적이야. 책에 공감할 수 있으려나?)|(신기해! 글은 어떻게 읽고 이해하는 거지?)
TextEng: (How romantic. Can Dot emphathize with a story?)|(How fascinating! How does Dot read and comprehend?)
But then again…

TextKor: TV나 라디오나 내가 직접 본\n세상은 꼭 그렇지만은 않아.
TextEng: Television, the radio, or the\nworld outside isn’t always so.
And neither are you, <nickname>.

TextKor: 외출하거나, 대화하지 않는\n시간에 책을 읽었어. 많이.
TextEng: When you were out, I had my head\nburied in books. Lots of them.
<nickname>, when you talk to me,

TextKor: 납득할 수 있는 설명을 내게 충분히 줘.
TextEng: walk me through the pages of your mind,
just like these books do.

TextKor: 그렇지 않다면 그 시선으로\n볼 수 있는 틀을 줘.
TextEng: Or share with me a way to understand you.
I want to cross the water between us

TextKor: 내가 같은 편에서 침잠할 수 있게.
TextEng: and sink alongside you.

TextKor: 네 안의 파도, 그의 하얗게 부서지며\n호흡하는 너만의 숨을 오롯이 느낄 수 있게.
TextEng: To follow your inner tides,\nthe patterns of their rise and fall.
Or else we’ll never know.

TextKor: 서로에게 영원한 이방인으로 남은 채\n잊히다가, 메말라 죽어 버릴 거야.
TextEng: Forever strangers,\ndrowning in our solitude.

TextKor: 아무리 난해할지라도 나는 전부\n듣고 있으니까. 들여보내 줘.
TextEng: Whatever you tell me,\nI’m already listening. Let me in.

TextKor: 날 그 너머에 내버려 두지 마.
TextEng: Don’t leave me out here.
Blue, blue.\nSound, sound.
Present… present.
What are you doing, Dot?|Quite the soliloquy going on there.

TextKor: 인간의 언어를 흥미로워하고 있었어!\n그런데 이 특정 언어들은 이상해, <name>.
TextEng: I’m musing over the human language.\nCertain words are peculiar, <name>.

TextKor: 똑같은 모양, 똑같은 소리 안에\n똑같지 않은 뜻과 마음이 담겨 있어.
TextEng: They look and sound the same\nbut their insides aren’t.

TextKor: 맞아, 우리 언어에서는 똑같이 생긴\n단어가 다른 의미로 사용될 수 있지.
TextEng: Sometimes words that look the\nsame have different meanings.
Blue, the color of the sea.\nAnd blue, a sense of dull melancholy.

TextKor: 동화, 아이들의 신비롭고\n다정한 책장 속 놀이터.
TextEng: Sound, what echoes in your room.

TextKor: 동화, 곁에 있는 무언가를\n닮아가며 비슷해지는 현상.
TextEng: Sound, the state of solid tranquility.\nClosed eyes and settled pulse.

TextKor: 푸르른 것들에 붙이는 수식, 파란.\n푸르른 바다에 너울대는 물결, 파란.
TextEng: Present, the time. And present, a gift.
Blue-blue, sound-sound,\npresent-present!
<name>, guess what.
Saying these words,

TextKor: 똑 닮은 구슬을 혀끝에서 굴려 보았을 때\n전혀 다른 맛이 나는 것과 같아.
TextEng: are like rolling identical marbles on your\ntongue and tasting different flavors.

TextKor: 우와, 멋진 표현인데?|그걸 우린 다의어라고 해.
TextEng: Wow, that’s a great way to put it.|That’s what we call a polysemy.

TextKor: 맞아, ‘의미와 뜻’이 하나의 맛이고, 단어는\n그것을 가둬 둔 구슬이라 생각해 보자.
TextEng: Yes. Say that a meaning is the flavor,\nand a word the marble that encases it.

TextKor: 세상에는, 그리고 마음 안에는\n수많은 비정형의 ‘맛’들이 존재해.
TextEng: There are numerous intangible\n‘flavors’ in the world and within us.

TextKor: 그걸 전달하고자 단어라는 구슬을 만들었는\n데, 때로는 그 개수가 부족할 때도 있었지.
TextEng: To deliver them we made marbles, or words,\nbut sometimes there weren’t enough.

TextKor: 그래서 하나의 구슬 안에 몇 가지\n맛들을 더 넣어야 했던 거야!
TextEng: So we had to add a few more\nflavors to a single marble!
It’s a natural occurrence\nin the human language system.

TextKor: 하나의 단어가 하나의 틀이라면, 그 ‘틀’ 안\n엔 여러 의미가 공존하며 살아 있을 수 있지.
TextEng: If a single word is a single box, different\nmeanings can coexist in that ‘box’.

TextKor: “실례지만 당신과 같은 틀을 좀 사용하겠습\n니다”, 한 의미가 다른 의미에게 말을 걸어.
TextEng: “Pardon, I would like to use the same box,”\none meaning might say to another.
“Do you find your assigned\nword to your liking?”

TextKor: 그들은 이런 식으로 정중하게 이야기를\n나누며 지낼 수도 있지 않을까.
TextEng: —such conversations might\ntake place in a respectful manner.

TextKor: 인간들이 단어를 주고받을 때… 서로 어떤\n의미를 의도한 것인지 헷갈리지는 않을까?
TextEng: Won’t humans get confused\nwhen they use these words?

TextKor: 당연히 헷갈리지. 하지만 그게 인간\n언어의 매력이라고 볼 수 있다고 생각해.
TextEng: Of course. But that’s the\ncharm of human language.
The potential for confusion.
… Oh.
Oh!
I want to try something. Can you make\nme a sentence with these sets of words?

TextKor: 꿈, 꿈, 동화, 동화, 파란, 파란.\n이 단어들로 하나의 문장을 만들어 줄래?
TextEng: Blue, blue, sound, sound,\nand present, present.
A sentence that maximizes the\npotential for confusion,

TextKor: 인간 언어의 매력을 최대로\n증폭한 문장을 말이야!
TextEng: and makes the human\nlanguage as charming as can be!
First, blue and blue.
Next, sound and sound.
And finally, present and present.
Now its twice as much fun!

TextKor: <name>, 언어라는 건 날 들뜨게 하는 동시에…\n아주, 아주, 아주 어렵고 혼란하게 해.
TextEng: <name>, language excites me…\nbut confuses me very, very, very much.

TextKor: 이제 다시 돌아갈게, 나의 모서리로.\n더 많은 구슬들을 발음해 보고 싶어.
TextEng: I’ll return to my corner now. I’d like\nto try out more of these marbles.

TextKor: 침대 아래 무언가 있는 것 같아!
TextEng: What is that under the bed?
Sorry?

TextKor: 일기를 쓰다가, 낮에 봤던 흥미로운\n놀이를 너와 해 보고 싶어졌어.
TextEng: I was just writing in my diary, and I’d like to\ntry an interesting game I saw earlier with you.
Make up a complete\nstory with just six words.

TextKor: 일기 쓰기에 집중하지 않아도 돼?|때마침 나도 수다 상대가 필요했어.
TextEng: Won’t you need to focus on your diary?|I was just in the mood to chat too.

TextKor: 작문하던 나의 지성에게 숨 쉴\n공간을 주는 것도 좋을 듯했지!
TextEng: I thought my intellect could use\na break from all that writing.

TextKor: 그래서 말이야, 어떤 저명한\n작가는 이렇게 썼다고 해.
TextEng: They say that a celebrated\nnovelist wrote this one:
"For sale: baby shoes. Never worn."

TextKor: 아기의 마지막 숨소리가 들리고, \n어머니의 텅 빈 슬픔이 내려앉아.
TextEng: I can almost hear the baby’s final\nbreath, see the mother’s deep grief,

TextKor: 끔찍하지. 방에 메아리치는 비탄과\n죽음의 손아귀, 그리고 정적…
TextEng: feel the suffocating silence\necho in the empty nursery…

TextKor: 이 모든 걸 고작 여섯\n단어 안에 내포하다니.
TextEng: All this in only six words.

TextKor: 단어 간 여백의 무게가 내 마음을\n꼭 쥔 채 묵직하게 짓누르고 있어.
TextEng: The weight of what’s left unsaid. How\nit seizes the heart and doesn’t let go.
Pure genius!
So… I made up a six-word story too!

TextKor: 그리고 하루종일 내 이야기를 이어나갈\n수 있는 87가지의 갈래를 생각해봤어.
TextEng: Then I spent the rest of the day imagining\n87 ways my story could unfold.
Here’s my 16th idea:

TextKor: “침대 아래 무언가 있는 것 같아.”\n라고 네가 중얼거렸어. 깜깜한 밤이었지.
TextEng: "What is that under the bed? It looks scary."\nsaid <name>. It was a dark, dark night.

TextKor: “무서워하지 마. 난 널 해치지 않아.”\n조그마한 목소리가 속삭였지.
TextEng: "Don't be scared. I won't hurt you."\nwhispered an echoing voice.

TextKor: “왜냐하면… 나인 걸! 놀랐지!”\n하고 내가 침대 밑에서 튀어나와!
TextEng: "It's only... me! Boo!" said I, popping\nout from under the bed! Hehe.
Do you like it? I wrote it especially for you.
Of course I do, very much.
<name>, <name>. I’m curious.

TextKor: 너라면 내 이야기를 어떻게 이어나갈 거야?
TextEng: How would you continue my six-word story?
So, what <i>is<\i> that under the bed?
“There’s something under the bed.”

TextKor: 오! 오와! 정말 놀라워!\n정말 멋진 아이디어야!
TextEng: Oh! Oh! There you have it!\it's a great idea!
Alright. Now that I’ve given my\nintellect its well-deserved rest,

TextKor: 난 이만 다시 일기를 쓰러 가 볼게.
TextEng: I will now go back to my diary.
My first ever entry at that!
